title: 105_hr4004
content:
TITLE I--CASA MALPAIS

SEC. 101. CONGRESSIONAL FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. The Casa Malpais National Historic Landmark, one of the largest Mogollon communities in the US, includes a 58-room masonry pueblo, Great Kiva complex, and catacomb chambers. Designated as a national historic landmark in 1964, Arizona and Springerville are working on interpretation and preservation. The purpose of this title is to aid in preserving and interpreting Casa Malpais for the public benefit. SEC. 102. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. The Secretary of the Interior can enter into cooperative agreements with Arizona and Springerville for technical and financial assistance to maintain Casa Malpais National Historic Landmark. The agreements may grant access for interpretation purposes and prohibit alterations to the landmark. No changes or alterations can be made to the landmark without mutual agreement between the Secretary of the Interior and the other parties involved in the agreements. SEC. 103. Appropriations authorized for financial assistance under this title. TITLE II - Lower Eastside Tenement: SEC. 201. Findings and purposes. Congress finds that immigration and cultural diversity are key factors in defining American identity, with a significant number of citizens tracing their ancestry to immigrants. The late 19th and early 20th centuries saw a surge in immigration to the United States, particularly in the Lower East Side neighborhood of Manhattan. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City stands as a testament to the humble buildings that housed immigrants during that time. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City is owned and operated as a museum dedicated to interpreting immigrant life in the neighborhood. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1994 and found to be nationally significant by the National Park Service. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City is suitable for inclusion in the National Park System to preserve immigrant life in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, interpret tenement architecture, and enhance the interpretation of other national monuments in the area. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street on Manhattan Island in New York City is designated as a national historic site and is managed by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. The Secretary of the Interior oversees this historic site. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City is designated as a national historic site and affiliated with the National Park System. The site's operation and interpretation are coordinated with other national monuments related to the immigrant experience in the United States. The Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site is owned and operated by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, a nonprofit institution. SEC. 204. MANAGEMENT OF THE SITE. The Secretary can enter a cooperative agreement with the Lower East Side Tenement Museum for marking, interpreting, and preserving a national historic site. Financial and technical assistance can be provided for preservation-related improvements. A management plan will be developed to define roles and responsibilities for interpretation and preservation. Interpretation and programming for the Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site, Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, and Castle Clinton national monuments will be coordinated to enhance the stories at each site within 2 years. The Secretary is not authorized to acquire property at 97 Orchard Street or assume financial responsibility for the Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site. SEC. 205. APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out this title.
